summary.seg: Fitzwilliam Museum, MS 261 is a luxurious manuscript, the likes of which were only affordable to royalty or high aristocracy. In this case, its patron was a royal lady of remarkable stature. Decorative motifs in the borders reveal that it was copied for Lady Margaret Beaufort (1443-1509), the mother of Henry VII and the founding matriarch of the Tudor dynasty. Lady Margaret was a strong and politically astute woman, who played an active role in the plot to overthrow Richard III and place her son on the throne of England. It was also her plan to marry her son to Elizabeth of York, uniting the bloodlines of York and Lancaster and bringing about the end to the Wars of the Roses. Among other things, Lady Margaret was a major patron of learning, and her royal patronage was instrumental in the foundation of Christ's College and St John's College in Cambridge. She was also actively involved in the book trade, commissioning and buying hundreds of manuscripts and printed books, and this manuscript is but one of many books associated with her: the distinctive Beaufort badge of a portcullis appears in decorated borders throughout the manuscript, and on f. 1r is also between a dragon gules and greyhound argent, symbols subsequently used by supporters of Henry VII.

The manuscript's contents are entirely concerned with the plague. It contains medical texts, including both Latin (f. 1r) and English (f. 9v) versions of the Canutus plague treatise, as well as two versions of John of Burgundy's Tractatus de morbo epidemiae. There are also regimen texts, which give instructions on diet: the Regimen sanitatis Aristotilis ad Alexandrum magnum of pseudo-Aristotle (ff. 19r-20r) and John Lydgate's Dietary (ff. 30v-32v). The presence of such texts among plague treatises can be explained by physiological theories of the day: that the disease was transmitted by corrupt air and that the body was more susceptible to infection if it was not kept in balance. Thus, maintaining a healthy diet and habits was considered paramount in preventing the disease. In addition to these medical and dietary guides, the reader of this manuscript could seek the intervention of higher powers, through a selection of prayers and hymns for use in times when the pestilence struck. In one of these (f. 27r), a series of spiritual 'remedyes' are prescribed: 'Repentance of heart, shrift of mouth (i.e. oral confession), fulfilling of penance, injoined prayer, fasting, alms, processions with the litany, private devotions and penance, and willingly saying prayers at masses', with examples of 'orisons', collects and antiphons following in the text.

msItem.title: Tractatus de regimine pestilencio
msItem.author: Pseudo-Benedictus Canuti
Johannes Jacobi [Jean Jacme or Jasmes] or Montpellier
msItem.rubric: 1r Ad honorem sancte et indiuidue trinitatis: glorioseque virginis marie . et ad vtilitatem reipublice pro conseruacione sanorum ac reformacione lapsorum volo aliqua de pestilencia que nos frequencius inuadit ex dictis medicorum magis autenticorum scribere . Et primo De signis pronosticis eius. Secundo de causis. Tercio de Remedijs. Quarto de confortaminibus cordis et principalium membrorum. Quinto et ultimo de fleubothomia.
msItem.incipit: 1r De signis pronosticis pestilencie. Signa pronostica pestilencie septem ad presens assignantur.
msItem.explicit: 9r Si quis autem secundum modum predictum se rexerit . huius morbi contagiosi pericula bene euadat . prestante domino nostro ihesu Christo (sine quo nichil fieri potest) qui est omnipotens et gloriosus et laudabilis et benedictus . cum Intemerata virgine Maria matre eius in secula seculorum. Amen.
msItem.finalRubric: 9r Tractatus de Regimine pestilentico domini Kanuti Episcopi Arusiensis ciuitatis regni Dacie artis medicine expertissimi professoris finem habet.

msItem.title: Tractatus de regimine pestilencio [English translation]
msItem.author: Pseudo-Benedictus Canuti
Johannes Jacobi [Jean Jacme or Jasmes] or Montpellier
msItem.rubric: 9v Here begynneth a litil booke the whiche traytied and reherced many goode thinges necessaries for the infirmite and grete sekenesse called Pestilence the which often tymes enfecteth vs made by the most expert doctour in phisike Bisshop of Arusiens.
msItem.incipit: 19v At the reuerence and worship of the blessed trinite and of the glorious virgyn saynt Marye and the conseruacioun of the commyn wele of alle cresten people as wele for them that ben hole as for remedye of them that ben seke. I the Bisshop of Arusiens doctour of phisike wille wryte by the most expert and famous doctours auctorised in phisike somme thinges of the infirmite of pestilence whiche dayly infecteth and sone suffreth vs to departe oute of this lyfe.
msItem.explicit: 19v These remedyes be sufficient to eschewe this grete sekenesse with the helpe of almighty god to whome be euerlastyng laude and praysing worlde withouten ende. AMEN.

msItem.title: Regimen sanitatis Aristotilis ad Alexandrum magnum
msItem.author: Pseudo-Aristotle
msItem.rubric: 19r Regimen sanitatis Aristotilis ad Alexandrum magnum .
msItem.incipit: 19r Aristotelis autem scribens Alexandro magno ait. O alexander cum sit homo corpus corruptibile visum est michi scribere vtilia ex secretis artis medicine.
msItem.explicit: 20r Octauum est vt vtaris croco in tuis cibarijs quia calorem naturalem viuificat . digestionem confortat . leticiam inducit . senectutem tardat . et humores prohibet a putrefactione etcaetera. Finis.

msItem.title: Plague tract
msItem.rubric: 20r Hec sequens litera tempore pestilenciali apud Oxoniam per magistros et doctores. Anno Henrici quarti .viijo. facta fuit per eosdem missa maiori ciuitatis Londiniarum ubi per phisicos apothecarios . et alios quam plures maxime erat laudata.
msItem.incipit: 20r Dilectissime frater ut intellexi multum times pro instanti pestilencia quasi in ipsa sis moriturus.
msItem.explicit: 23r Item caueas ab omnibus speciebus calidis etcaetera

msItem.title: Tractatus de morbo epidemiae [English translation]
msItem.author: John of Burgundy
msItem.rubric: 23r Here begynneth a nobyll tretyse made by a right worthy physician named Maister John Burdeux agaynes the malady of the pestilence . whiche tretyse ys departed in .iiij. chapitours . The first telleth how a man shall kepe hym in tyme thereof. The secunde tellyth how hit cometh. The thirde telleth ageynst hit. The iiij.th telleth how a man shall kepe hym in his sykenesse.
msItem.incipit: 23v Capitulum primum. The clerke saith in the first chapiter that for fawte of good rewle in dyetyng in metes and drynkes men falle ofte tymes in this sykenesse therfore when pestilence regnes in cuntry whoso wyll be keped therfro hym nedys to kepe hym from surfette and outrageous excesse of metes an drynkes and vse no bathes ne ouer muche swetyng for specialy these thoo open the porys of the body and make he venymous eyre sone to entre and destruye the lyfly spyrites of man woman or chylde
msItem.explicit: 26v And whoso is in the sykenesse doo be tyme as it is sayde in the secunde chapiter and rewle and dyette hymself after the thirde chapiter . And trust with the grace of god to be made hole and fare well

msItem.title: Medical advice for avoiding the plague
msItem.incipit: 26v Hit hath been taght in tyme of pestilence for a souerain medicyn a man to take yche day at noon .iij. smale croppes of Rewe .iij. leuys of yong tansay .iij. leues of sauge and fayre wasshed to be chewed in a mannys mouth . Receyuyng the Juse and lycour of the sayd herbes in to the stomake and to spytt oute the draffe.
msItem.explicit: 26v-27r Also what man supposeth hym take with pestilence in his body and namely aboute his cheste or breste on alle wyse eschewe to ete oystyrs and namely custumably . for kynde of oystyrs is to geder to hym felones and corrupte maters as an adyamant draweth yren

msItem.title: Prayers against the plague
msItem.incipit: 27r Syth pestilence commynly fallyth for synne Regnyng among the people and other dyuerse vengeaunce after rightfull ordynaunce of god hit behoueth first to vse gostly remedye so that god may be pleased and turne away his wrath from hem whiche remedyes be these . Repentance of herte schryffte of mouth fulfyllyng of penaunce Inioyned prayer fastyng almesdede processions with the letanye . pryue deuocions and pryue penaunce wylfully takyng speciall orysons in masses assyned
msItem.explicit: 29r Per hoc signum tau T a pestilencia fame et paupertate et ab omni infirmitate corporis et anime libera nos ihesu . hic est titulus triumphalis . Jhesus nazarenus rex iudeorum . Christus venit in pace et deus homo factus est ihesus . in nomine ihesu signo me hoc signo tau T In nomine patris . etcaetera.
msItem.note: Invokes St Sebastian, St Anthony, and the Tau cross, for protection against the plague.

msItem.title: Medical advice for avoiding the plague
msItem.incipit: 29r Bodely helpis be these to kepe the fro sykenesse such as be full of blood shulde blede in tyme of hele oonys in a monyth in somer tyme on the right syde of the body on the ryght arme or on the right foote.
msItem.explicit: 30v Also other as Ryche men and elder a medicyne to take a good potagarare and to vse a lytyll sponfull att .iij. tymes in the weke take powder of tria sandaly of conserue of Roses and powder of a medicyne callled plites cum musto of yche on halfe an vnce these shall be medylt to gider and a quartroun of sugre put therto and all medeled to geder . Whoso taketh this sekenes of pestilence yf age woll suffre hym he most be kepid wakyng .xxiiij. owres and the hede most be schauen and anoynted ofte of Juse of Syngrene water of Roses wymmen mylke vynegre medeled togider and drynke small drynke a ij. dayes with soure brede and be let blood anon yf age and strenghte wyll . Also bolus armoniacus is goode for the pestilence to drynke with ale fastyng.

msItem.title: Dietary
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 30v Here followeth the most Riche dietarie
msItem.incipit: 30v For helthe of body couere for colde tyn hede
msItem.explicit: 32r Thus in .ij. thynges standith all þe welthe / Of soule and body who so lyst them fewe / Moderate fode genderyth to man his helthe / And all surfetes doth from hym remeue / And charite to the soule ys dewe .
msItem.finalRubric: 32v This receyte bought ys of no potikary / Of maister Antony nother of maister hugh / To all Indifferent most Rychest dietarie. Finis.

foliation.note: Folios [i]-[ii] and [iii]-[iv] are modern translucent paper flyleaves.
Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords written in the lower right corners of the last versos of quires.

layout.seg: Ruled in red ink, frame and line ruling. Single columns. 25 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Folios 1r-32v copied by a single hand in a Bâtarde script.

decoNote.p: One full scatter border, including flovers, portcullises, a dragon and greyhound, in colours on a yellow (imitation gold) ground on f. 1r.
Partial scatter borders, including flowers and portcullises in colours on yellow (imitation gold) grounds, on ff. 9v, 19r, 20r, 23v [also featuring a dragon and greyhound], and 30v.

One large (6 lines) blue initial 'S' with the Beaufort painted in colours painted over, in a frame with a yellow (imitation gold) ground that is continuous with the full scatter border on the same page (f. 1r).

Large (3 to 6 lines) blue and red initials with foliate motifs drawn with white sprays on the letters and large flowers in colours inside the letters, in frames and on coloured grounds that are continuous with the partial scatter borders on the same page (ff. 9v, 19r, 20r, 23v and 30v [featuring a rose surmounted by a crown]).
Line-fillers of framed blue foliate motifs on red grounds with streaks of yellow (imitation gold) throughout.
Large (2 lines) framed initials in pale blue and blue on red grounds with streaks of yellow (imitation gold) throughout.
Introductions and headings written in red ink throughout.
Small (1 line) regulal initials highlighted with yellow throughout.
Blue paraphs in frames with red grounds throughout.
Underlining of text in red ink.

physDesc.additions: Quire numbers (Arabic numerals) in pencil added to the lower right corners of the first rectos of quires in modern times.

binding.p: Modern plain white leather binding over wooden boards; four raised bands on the spine with red sewing thread. Red speckled fore, top, and tail edges.
Binding height: 210 mm; width: 155 mm; depth: 25 mm.

provenance.p: Lady Margaret Beaufort (1443–1509) Beaufort, Margaret, 1443–1509, Countess of Richmond and Derby: probably made for her after the accession of Henry VII (r. 1485-1509), her son, as indicated by the presence of the Beaufort coat of arms that she bore inside the decorative initial on f. 1r: France modern and England quarterly within a bordure compony argent and azure. Additionally, the Beaufort badge, a portcullis, appears four times in the full border, together with the dragon gules and greyhound argent that were used as heraldic supporters by Henry VII. The Beaufort Portcullis repeatedly occurs in the partial borders, as well as the dragon and greyhound that feature again in the partial border on f. 23v (see Wormald and Giles (1982), pp. 195-96). The Red Rose of Lancaster surmounted by a crown features inside a large decorated initial on f. 30v. As Urquhart (1986) has observed, the daisies ('marguerites') painted in the manuscript's borders also refer to Margaret Beaufort.

history.acquisition: Purchased by the Fitzwilliam Museum from Maggs Bros.Maggs Bros. in 1902.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the descriptions provided by Francis Wormald and Phyllis M. Giles, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Additional Illuminated Manuscripts in the Fitzwilliam Museum Acquired between 1895 and 1979 (Excluding the McClean Collection), 2 vols (Cambridge: Cambridge University Library, 1982) and Heraldry at the Fitzwilliam: Catalogue of an Exhibition of Heraldry at the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, September and October, 1970 (London, 1970), no. 44.

availability.p: Visitors to the Fitzwilliam Museum who wish to consult Collection material are required to apply to the Museum in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Fitzwilliam Museum: Study Room.
